instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5VS4_EN: What is PP5VS4_EN? P5VS4_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP5V_S4 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This is a waterdamaged board with damage around the battery connector area. I get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, green light on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is there as well, but no _s4 power rails. <SIGNAL>PP5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is only 0.4 V. Also resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 50 ohms measured from L7560. When i plug in the charger <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> gets hot, so i suppose this is the culprit. Are these chips generic? or do i need one from a donor board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hmm, dead PCH :(. Start with replacing that first. BIOS will also need fixing if you get this board going again, but that is the least of your worries.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey Duke, one more question for customer expectation management, from what i understand i will need a donorboard for the <CHIP>U1100</CHIP>, reballing etc. and after that what will still need to happen to the bios?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: oh and also, do i need this specific board, or are there multiple options for the donor?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
if you can find a donor with the PCH and bios still on it, that is your first best option. If not, then its lottery if you get a good one from usual places. 

Once PCH is replaced and board works, we can help you in fixing the bios.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You probably won't find a donor 3787 with a PCH still on it. Get a new PCH slap it on there and see if it works. Once it works the BIOS can fixed with a clean ME region.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have a 3662 with the pch still on it, from a customer who did not want to continue the repair, i'll try that first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I'm having trouble removing this chip from the motherboard with the bga machine, does anybody know the temperature needed to remove the PCH from the newer models?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The same as always, the only difference is that the motherboard is a big heat sink doing his job, just let it reach the desired temp and the chip should come out like any other...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If you have issues with removing this you need more practice. This should be quite easy and 3662 boards are not really practice material! Use some shitty MCP board for this purpose.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="MaxFix, post: 23444"]I'm having trouble removing this chip from the motherboard with the bga machine, does anybody know the temperature needed to remove the PCH from the newer models?[/QUOTE]

Are you using thermocouples to see what temps you are getting top side and under BGA?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: We have practiced on easier boards, and have done multiple succesful gpu replacements, that's why it was a bit surprising. I'll let it bake a bit longer before trying to remove.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: A chip like this should lift in about 90 seconds. Any longer will just fry the chip and board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So it's been a while, but we have finally received a 'new' pch from china. I slapped it on the board, and the short to ground is gone. The machine seems to respond to smc reset, but i am still not getting <SIGNAL>PP5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>, or any of the higher power rails.. does this have to do with the clean ME region that the smc needs? Or should the machine boot if everything is ok?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This could be anything from bad soldering on your "new" PCH or a dead CPU. I would not waste time on this one.
